ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read a book called The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! In this book, we saw many colorful pictures of people and animals with different expressions.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the words appeared and wandered. Use the Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of different words we read about. We will study them to understand how to express them through an action.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Examine Look at the picture on the card. Ask children what they see. Ask if they see an action or not.
What’s the Meaning? Ask children to discuss with a partner what the meaning of the word is. Ask them to discuss how knowing the meaning of the word can help them act it out.
Acting It Out Ask children to think about what action can show this word. Have them act out the word.
Extend Ask children if they can act out the word with a different action.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Expressing Yourself Invite children to talk about the actions they used to show the meaning of the word.

Show Kindness to Others Invite children to talk about how noise can bother others. Remind them that people try to care for each other. Ask them to discuss how there are good times to be noisy and other times to be quiet as a way of caring for others.

Point to the photo on a Picture Card. Ask: What do you see? Do you see an action? Then if it is an action, ask: When might you do this action? Can you still act out the word? Repeat with the other Picture Cards.

Ask children to use three emotions seen in the book and tell a tale incorporating these three emotions. Ask: What does the word tale mean? How is a tale like a story? How might you use the words happy, sad, and surprised to tell a tale?

Young children are usually better at learning a new language than adults. Adults may be afraid that they will say something incorrectly in English. On the other hand, young children are less inhibited and willing to take risks. Create a stress-free environment in which children enjoy trying out new words and phrases, one where their home language and English are both celebrated.

Consider doing this activity in a large-group space, where children can listen to music and act out each word. This activity would give them the opportunity to move their bodies to demonstrate the meaning of the word. Whole-body movement activates memory and listening, and helps children develop strength.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read the book The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! today, we saw different expressions through nonverbal cues in the illustrations.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word conflict. Use the Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of people with different feelings. You will use your knowledge of past experiences and the illustrations in the book to help you decide if the picture shows conflict or no conflict.
Lay the Picture Card face down on the table.
Grab one Picture Card and show it to your partner.
Put it in a pile for either conflict or no conflict.
As you place the Picture Card in the correct pile, explain to your partner why you are putting it there.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue the activity using the next Picture Card as children change roles.
Talk About Emotions Invite children to discuss one of the Picture Cards with a partner. Ask the partners to work together to act out the action on the Picture Card.
Encourage children to work together in small groups to act out the word together. Invite children to actively talk through their actions to help guide other children.
Have children work with a partner to draw new Picture Cards that fit in the category: conflict or no conflict.

Invite multi-language learners to use movement to show you different emotions, such as happy, sad, funny, and peaceful. These physical and visual cues will support language learners and help them participate in the activity even as their language skills develop.

Consider doing this activity on the floor or at a desk. Encourage children to actively engage their hands as they work on grasping and picking up the Picture Cards. This activity gives them the opportunity to move their hands to practice grasping flat objects, such as playing cards. This fine motor movement helps children develop motor memory.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read the book The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! today, we read about the gallito, or rooster, who did not stop singing. He would not be quiet no matter what Don Pepe took away from him.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word quiet. Use the Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at a picture and figure out if the picture shows something or somewhere quiet or not quiet.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one Picture Card and use the text on the back to ask if the picture shows something or somewhere that is quiet. Why or why not? Offer extra support or challenge as needed.
Sort Give the Picture Card to a child to line up in one of two columns: quiet or not quiet.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next Picture Card as children change roles.

Talk About It Talk together about what elements made each picture fall into the “quiet” category or the “not quiet” category. Invite children to make some of the noises they can hear in the pictures that were sorted into the “not quiet” category. Encourage children to use as many describing words as possible as they talk about the pictures.
Encourage children to talk about something that makes a loud noise that they have encountered before. Show them pictures from magazines to help trigger their memory.

Have children work with a partner to tell a story (tale) using different actions and sounds. Encourage children to be creative in their storytelling. If children are so inclined, have them draw a picture to represent the story.
Model and encourage children to use a physical response, in addition to speaking, to talk about the pictures. For example, they can roar like a lion or make honking noises like taxis do in cities.
Offer children the option to draw a response to the activity using pencils, crayons, or markers. Encourage children to talk as they draw, using as many describing words as possible.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Voice In Rabbit’s House today, we met different animals. Some of these animals were brave. Today we will see if we can listen and remember the order of when each animal came to Rabbit’s house.
In this activity, I will read to you different parts of the story, and I will ask you to tell me if I told the story in the correct order. If not, I will ask what the correct order should be.
Listen as I read and write these sentences on the board. Try to remember the story The Voice In Rabbit’s House.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Repeat the sentences as many times as children need in order to remember the story. If needed, go back and revisit the story for additional help.

Talk About Telling Stories Talk together about why it is important to tell a story in the correct order. Ask children if it was hard for them to remember what the order of animals was in the story. Encourage conversation, especially around any instances where a child was confused and changed their mind on the order of the story.
Review the images and the names of different animals being discussed. Encourage children to work together in small groups to talk and even act out the story as they remember it.

Have children work with a partner to tell a story (tale) using some or all of the animals in the story. Encourage children to be creative in their storytelling. If children are so inclined, have them draw a picture to represent the story.
You may wish to talk about the close connection between many English and Spanish words by using the word rhinoceros as an example (rinoceronte in Spanish).

Consider having children act out the scenes in a large space, such as the playground. This activity would give them the opportunity to move their bodies to demonstrate how the animal might move or sound. Whole-body movement activates memory and listening, and helps children develop strength.
